description:
Cephalopachus bancanus, also known as the Banka Slender Loris, is a small primate species that belongs to the family Lorisidae. It is native to the Indonesian island of Banka, located off the eastern coast of Sumatra.

The Banka Slender Loris is a nocturnal and arboreal species, spending most of its time in the trees. It has a slender and delicate build, with large eyes, long limbs, and a small, round head. The fur is typically grayish-brown in color, with a distinctive white stripe running from the forehead to the nose.

These primates are known for their slow and deliberate movements, which help them navigate the dense forest canopy. They are primarily solitary and territorial, and they feed on a variety of small insects, fruits, and flowers.

The Banka Slender Loris is classified as Vulnerable on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species, primarily due to habitat loss and fragmentation caused by deforestation and human encroachment. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect this unique and fascinating primate species.
